I've posted before that I sing with the National Philharmonic. But I shall elaborate! Back in February, the Philharmonic performed for the opening of the new Music Center at Strathmore in Maryland. Think Kennedy Center, only better. I'm not kidding -- this place is hands down, the most amazing facility I've seen. The concert hall is acustically engineered to have the best possible sound, and its awe-inspiring to look at. It seats roughly 2,000 I believe (though don't hold me to that), and is all hardwood, smooth silver metal, and wide open. It was designed by the same team that designed the Osawa Hall at Tanglewood (subtext: this is a big deal). Please check it out so you can see the amazement for yourself: http://tessy.strathmore.org/facilityrentals/musiccenter/photoalbum.asp?page=1 (If that doesn't work, go to www.strathmore.org and search for the photo album.) The thing that gets me is, that I SING HERE. I am a member of the National Philharmonic, and this is our home! I don't mean this to brag; I simply mean that I am blown-over by the fact that I'm a part of this. Its insane! Philharmonic life is awesome. The opening concert at Strathmore will forever be etched in my memory. We performed Beethoven's monumental Symphony No.9 (that's the "Ode to Joy" one that you all know), and it was magical. "Freude!!" (Joy!) we sang! And to make the experience even more meaningful, everyone I love was there: (Dad sings in the chorus too, so that's a given) Mom, Danny, Matthew, Jamie, Professor Huszti... it was unreal. The Gages and the Harbourts came too, and that was so wonderful to have them present. They were quite impressed. Being on stage with a professional choir is unreal. I still can't believe I'm in a professional chorus. Well... to be p.c. its semi-professional because the choir isn't paid... yet. The orchestra is paid. (Damn violins.) But, they're looking to pay us sometime in the next few years. Obviously, I don't sing with this group for the extra income. :-P I sing with them because I love them. Our sound is professional. The people are a blast. And our directors, Stan Engebretzen and Patrick Walders are phenomenal teachers/conductors. This past weekend, we just did Mozart's Requiem, which is eerily ironic, since the Pope died the same day. I suppose it was an appropriate performance. Personally, I sang better in the Mozart than I did in the Beethoven, but my voice is better suited to earlier music than the great Romantic stuff. No blasty-horned-helmet vibrato for me, thank-you-very-much. The Philharmonic Singers are amazing as well. Officially, I like singing with them better than the big group, mostly because my voice blends better there. We specialize in choral chamber music, rather than the large masterworks. That's the kind of music that truly makes my heart burst. The wrenching suspensions of early(typically) choral chamber music make my limbs quiver. This kind of music presses into me. There's nothing like it. The next big Philharmonic performance is Orff's Carmina Burana. While this is a fun piece, its not the most meaningful (the text is all about lusty wenches and beer-gulping abbots), nor is it all that musically challenging. Frankly, this is one of the works that my musical education has caused me to like less than I did before I majored in music. Oh well. It still has some cool moments. After that, our last concert of the season will be selections from Ravel's Daphnis et Chloe. (Appologies for lack of French accents; I don't know how to get them on LJ.) The Spring Singers concert is coming up in May. We're doing a shmultsy Mendholsson springtime set, the Busto Ave Maria, a 20th-century piece called "The Bluebird", Candide's "Best of All Possible Worlds" (oy), and the women are doing a Lux Aeterna by a female composer - Michelle Roueche - who apparently writes a lot like Patrick (Walders, our director). This piece is sooooo cool because in the middle, all of us do a free-form thing where each of us sings the main motive, but all at different times, as fast or slow as we want it, and in whole or part - essentially playing with the motive however we want. It is the coolest effect; when its done in the church we perform in, it will truly sound ethereal. *sigh* I love music. I'm in love with it, second behind Matthew. ;-)

Exciting update on the job front! Friday I received a call from Byron to let me know that they'd like me to come in for a third interview sometime either Monday or Tuesday. Yay!! He also said the pay is looking something like $13-$13.50/hr, so that's awesome! Before the thrid interview, however, I needed to fill out the formal application for employment, so he sent it to me via email. I spent Friday afternoon filling this thing out; it was insane. I had to write a statment concerning why I wanted to work with the Palau Association, and fill out a page on all of the jobs I've held in the last 10 years. Oy. Then, I had to write what church I belong to, and how I'm involved there. Eeep. So, I wrote that I am a member of Nativity Catholic, and that I teach CCD there. But I also wrote that I've been attending South Run Baptist, though I'm not yet a member. Yes, I said not yet. Funny, isn't it. Did you ever think I'd be a Baptist? Heh. But that's for another post. I faxed in the application, along with my original cover letter and resume, in case the Portland office wanted those as well. The third interview is via conference-call with the headquarters in Portland, Oregon. When I had the first interview, Byron told me that if they want me for interview #3, I'm essentially hired. So.... let's keep our fingers crossed and say some prayers. Today I got an email from Byron, saying he got my faxed application, and that they're looking at a Wednesday interview at the earliest. That's ok. I'm just glad to be having one. It looks like I might be about a week away from employment... but I won't celebrate until I know for sure.

As promised, here it is. Where shall I even start? So much has happened. Well, remember that awesome dental assistant job I interviewed for? The one that had great hours, an amazing benefits package, and was going to pay me a lot? Yeah. It seemed a shock to me, but two Saturdays ago I got a letter in the mail from the Dr's office, saying that they were sorry to inform me of the news, but they found someone else with "more particular credentials" for the job. A 'nice' way of saying they found someone who had previous dental experience. It was quite a blow for a number of reasons. One, I thought I might have had it. The interview went so well. The doctors really seemed to like me. They were very willing to train. And as I was leaving, the head doctor said, "Well, we're very interested. We just want to make sure you are too...?" To which I responded with an enthusiastic, "yes, very much so," and a smile. "Great!" he said. "We'll definitely be in touch, then!" So what went wrong? The only thing I can think of is that someone else came in for an interview after me and blew them away with prior dental experience. I don't mean to sound stuck up, but I did a damn good job in that interview. And they loved my resume. So, unless they were lying, I know they were interested. It doesn't make sense. Saturday, I was angry. Then mildly depressed. I felt pathetic. How is it that I can have an awesome degree, an above-average set of skills, an impressive resume, and I can't get a job? What's wrong with me? But, one is not productive if one dwells on her lost battle. So, I spent the rest of Saturday and Sunday in thought and reflection. A few weeks ago, Pastor Wayne informed me of a job opening with the Louis Palau festival for the DC area. He said they needed administrative assistants; the pay was $13-15/hr, no benefits, but in a Springfield office, the job lasts until October. Initially, I half wrote it off, since there weren't any benefits, but then I went through the whole dental assistant issue. I realized, right now, I'm uninsured and have no paycheck. If I was working with the festival, I'd have a paycheck. Maybe then I could at least insure myself. Monday I got down to business. I figured out insurance stuff with Mom's help, and I worked on a solid, heart-felt cover letter for the Festival people. The more I thought about this job, the more I felt it might be a really good opportunity for me. For those who don't know, the DC Festival with Louis Palau is one of many Palau festivals that hit major cities around the US and South America. Its focus is Christian Evangelism, but in ways that reach a modern audience. The best known Chrisian music artists perform, Christian extreme sports athletes put on demonstrations; there are talks with Louis Palau, an area for kids, lots of food, a sports zone, etc. And its all completely free. So, I told them about my faith in my cover letter. I put it on the line. And then I faxed it in, along with my resume, and waited. The next day I got a call. This Tuesday I had an interview. We opened in prayer. Three people interviewed me; Byron, Trish, and Amy. The first question they asked me wasn't for me to tell them about my prior jobs. They simply said, "tell us about yourself, and your faith. Tell us about your conversion experience." (In this context, 'conversion' simply means how I 'entered into a life in Christ'). So I told them. No holding back. I knew complete honesty might worry them a little (being I'm split in a Catholic and Baptist Church currently), but I figured I should just put it all out there. And that's what I did. They asked me about my job at Nordstrom, what I liked, what I didn't like. They asked me what causes stress in my life. They asked me how I delt with it. They told me about the Association's goals and mission. They asked me where I see myself in faith in 5-10 years. They even asked a little about Sweet Briar. I got a good vibe from them during the whole thing - it wasn't a high-pressured interview. The three of them genuinely seemed to care about me as a person. At the end, they told me that they had 6 or 7 more people to interview, so they should get back to me sometime in the next two weeks. Also, they told me that the interview process is in three stages: the first one (which I was currently involved in), a second interview with Doug, the head guy in the office, and a thrid interview with the Portland office by phone. Following that was a personality test, too. But, Byron said, "if they have you come in for that third phone interview, you're essentially hired." Then they asked me to close them in prayer. I prayed that they find the right person for the job, and that God put me, also, where I need to be. I asked that He bless us, and the Festival all together, and that the Festival help lead to true conversion for many. I left feeling good about the interview, but not overly confident. On my drive home, I thought about my dental job interview and experience. I figured that if they found someone who had more dental experience than me, surely the Festival people will find someone with a stronger church-rooted faith than me. I grimly laughed that prospect that even my faith might not be "marketable" enough. A little disheartened, I prayed. At that point it was in God's hands; I put everything on the line for those guys in the interview. They either were impressed by my honesty and my journey in faith, or they were worried that I'm not "firmly planted" in one congregation. A few minutes after I got home, the phone rang, and my mom brought it to me. "It's the Palau people," she said. Amy was on the phone. "Well, we discussed some things after you left -- heh, did you just get home? Anyhow, we'd like to know if you can come in tomorrow for the interview with Doug. How's 1:30?" She also told me that they'd like to see what I can do on Micorsoft Office programs, so the interview would be with Doug, and on a computer as well. Needless to say, I was rather plesantly surprised! They must have liked me! This was certainly a good sign. Perhaps they saw a little bit of what my faith looks like, in spite of the two-church thing. Tuesday night, I skipped choral rehersal (during performance week - its a miracle they're going to still let me perform on Saturday), and Matthew gave me a crash course in Word and Excel (we had briefly gone over Outlook the night before). Thank gosh, too, because the first thing the Festival office had me do yesterday was an excercise on Excel. Anyhow, I got through the computer excercise rather well, and they were seemingly encouraged. Then I had the round two of questions from Doug, supplimented by Trish and guy-whose-name-I-can't-remember. This time, the questions were more personality-based: Did I pull a lot of all-nighters in college? During a party, am I the one up on the tables dancing, or do I prefer to mingle? What books am I currently reading? What was a situation in my last job that was stressful? How did I handle it? Do I prefer order, or a little interruption? Do I get easily stressed out?.... etc. At the end of the questioning, Doug said he thought I'd enjoy the Database Coordinator position more so than the Receptions Operations position. Trish looked mildly puzzled, but didn't say anything at the moment. Doug was in a rush, but as he was getting up to leave, he said, "Great! Well, let's see if we can't get her on the phone today... oh - Trish, maybe you can show her what some of the tasks are for the Database Coordinator?" So Trish took me to her office where she proceeded to show me what was involved in Database Coordination. Eeeep. The more she showed me, the more alarmed I became (think countless hours of computer data-entry). Then she said that I'd also be responsible for maintaining the website. Ha! I must have really wowed them on Excel. :-P Then she said very kindly, "hey -- if you're not into this - and that's totally fine because it is kinda boring - just let me know, because we still really need a receptionist." So I asked her to tell me a little more about the receptions job, and then told her that I would MUCH prefer that. She smiled and laughed and said, "you know, I thought so! When Doug said 'Database Coordinator,' I was a little confused. I'll let him know." So, I gathered up my stuff, followed Trish out of her office, and shook hands with her and the guy-whose-name-I-can't-remember. Doug was in a meeting, but Trish said they'd be in touch with me sometime this week. And now? I continue to wait. I'm going to try not to get too excited about this job, because I really could. The people are all awesome. I would love to work in an office where the people pray together. And yeah, the job will look great on my resume, but mostly, the experience of working for a cause I believe in will be worth so much more. I figure I'll view it like a paid internship: no benefits and temporary, but something I do for the experience rather than the monetary value. Its an opportunity that I most likely will not have again: the opportunity to work in an office with faith-centered Christians, who are united in the greater cause of spreading the Good News. These people really live their faith. I've never had the chance to surround myself with a whole group of people like this before. It might really be what I need right now, too, especially since home is so devestatingly draining, and I can't fully be involved at South Run (the other church I'm attending, along with Nativity). This job would welcome my faith, instead of being burdened by it. But God's will be done. I suppose I'll hear soon enough.

So here's the scoop on the job front: Last Monday, I worked all day on preparing a fabulous cover letter for the job of Dental Assistant at a prominent Periodontology office in Burke and McLean. This is the second D.A. (heehe) job I applied for; the first never called me back, and after I called them back for two follow-ups, they told me the position had already been filled. Booo. So, last Monday I spent the day editing and re-editing. I edited online with Matthew while he was at work, and I emailed my letter and resume to his mom to look over as well. Mrs. Barclay has a habit of obtaining every job she applies for, so Matt and I figured her input couldn't hurt. :-P So, after I polished my letter with the help of Matthew's mom (she gave some awesome advice, let me tell you!), I prayed, and faxed it off to the Dr's office around 5PM, close of business day. The very next morning, I was awakened by a phone call from the office (8:50 AM, mind you!). "Hello, Kristin? This is S---- from Dr.------- and Dr. -----'s office. We recieved your letter and resume this morning, and the doctors looked it over and well, honestly, they were very impressed. They're quite excited, and they'd like you to come in for an interview. How's next Tuesday?" WOO! So, fast-forward to today, the interview day. It was awesome! I'll spare a detail-by-detail account, but essentially, they really liked me and I really liked them. YES! The practice is excellent -- the doctors have won numerous awards for being at the front of their 'industry.' The office was clean and professional, the staff was friendly, and the doctors were friendly as well. I nailed all of the questions, and they appeared to be increasingly impressed. All in all, it was a lovely interview. I wasn't overly nervous, and they didn't try to make me nervous. The profile: I would work at both offices, Burke and McLean. Benefits are awesome: Medical plan covers 75% of medical costs (wow). 401K is available. And the salary: $16/hr STARTING. That's $32,000!!! WOOO! And its a standard 35-40 hour work-week, hours from 7AM-4PM (5PM on bad days occasionally if its insanely busy for some reason). And there's opportunity for salary growth, up to ~$22/hour. So, this is all very exciting. I wasn't offered the job right then and there, but it looks promising. The main doctor said he was very interested and that they would get back to me sometime this week, and let me know either way. So, say some prayers!! This could really be good. In this job, I would get a chance not only to work with people, but to actually help people. And who knows where my ministry can go with a job like this. I'm excited. I really hope this all works out. Thank you, Father for this successful interview! Your will be done here.

I realized that I haven't been posting any outwardly personal updates lately, so I figured I'd fix that for those interested parties. I know I have a fan club out there somewhere. :-P Anyhow so yes. Where shall I begin? Jobs One word to describe the job search and quest for finding out what it is I really want to do: confusing. Its beyond confusing, really. See, I go back and forth. Do I need to be fulfilled in my job, or do I just need a job to accomodate the things in my life that are already fulfilling? (This is a rhetorical question, mind you.) After I answer that, I need to think about two different paths to take: teaching or not-teaching. I think a part of me is always going to be a teacher, whether its doing it as a career, or teaching Sunday school. If I go the teaching route, I'd probably teach elementary music (Tiff, I could use your advice on some stuff sometime, regarding that!), although that could change. But, I am not certified. I could teach privately, but that doesn't earn me as much as public school teaching. So... ok... get certified, right? Sure! Anyone want to lend me $8-10 thousand for the certification program here at GMU? Yeah. And let me tell you, the idea of taking another loan is enough to make me cry. Not to mention the certification program is a year-long program -- if you're doing it as a full-time student! So, suffice it to say, this is a long and difficult (and expensive) road to get into a job I'm not entirely sure I'd love. So then we have the non-teaching jobs. What am I looking at? Well, you may laugh, but honestly, I am intrigued by two possible job-prospects as a Dental Assistant. It sounds nuts, I know. But they're willing to train, and its a job that I think could be kinda cool. Plus, its a 9-5, M-F kind of gig. I won't have to plan lessons or deal with school parents. And, it would give me a set of marketable skills to take around with me, should I eventually move away from NoVa. Yeah... we'll talk about that next. NoVa I never thought I'd say it but: I am not in love with NoVa. In fact, its grating on me. Its over-crowded and loud and constantly busy. There is no such thing as "rush hour" because its always rush hour. Yes, we have nice shopping. And yes we have nice organic food markets. But I'm not sure how much longer I can take the people-smog and the congestion. Honestly, its freaking hard to breathe around here. And everyone is a clone: a suit-wearing-DC-jobing 20-40-something who is making a great paycheck, but can't afford a puny townhouse. Bleh. A tiny one-bedroom apartment here is at least $1200, and if you want an efficency apartment in the ghetto, you can pay the mere $800 a month and risk your life. Fun. And then there's the mentality. A frightening "all about me" attitude (though I know this is everywhere), mixed with a "we're better" arrogance. Around here, if you aren't one amongst the clones, you're freakish. But more than that -- you're a loser. If you don't have a DC alphabet-soup job, you must be lazy. If you don't have a Lexus, you must be unmotivated. If you're not dating a lawyer, you must have low-standards. Or else you are guilty of low self-esteem, upon which case you should visit your shrink because everyone has them anyway. And don't forget to hit the chain-owned gym afterward. And bring your Starbucks back to your $gazillion mansion, where you hate your spouse, and your kids are still chilling with their nanny because you simply can't miss the next Oprah. I never thought I'd say it but: I am not in love with NoVa. Faith While we're on the topic of things I never thought I'd say: I'm not entirely Catholic. Not that I spit on my upbringing or denounce the faith of my family, but me - Kristin - I don't think I'm entirely capable of wearing that title anymore. So what am I, then? Christian. Whole-heartedly. Often I feel like shouting to the world: I love Jesus! Ha! Am I like Falwell's clan down in Lynchburg? No. Certainly not in style. But I am convicted now more than I ever have been in the authenticity of the Christian faith, and of the Triune God: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. I don't have all the answers. And I won't ever have all the answers. All I can say is that my faith was very 2-dimentional before. I knew about God. And now He's 3-dimentional. He has depth. Rather than knowing about God, I feel like I actually know God a little. He has become real to me. He has proven His presence in my life in countless ways. And the more I learn in my faith, the closer I grow to Him. To talk about my faith even under the sectioned-off paragraphs of this entry is contrary to my understanding of it. Faith is my life's umbrella, in a sense. It spans over all aspects of my life, and 'governs' each aspect accordingly. My faith in God, His Son Jesus, and the Holy Spirit, is the compass for my life. All other things are secondary. As St.Paul said, "I want to live my life for Christ." The problem: this is causing an uproar in my family. I am constantly (and I mean that in the strongest sense) dealing with conflict regarding my faith. Why? Because my faith is no longer completely "Catholic." Both of my parents have flipped out on me on more than one occasion, and my brother jabs whenever he can. They take it as a personal offense. They hear me speak, but they don't listen. And on rare occasions, when they are trying to really understand me, they usually completely miss the mark. Its a vicious frustrating circle of miscommunication. I feel like half the time I must be speaking in another language. And then I realize -- I am. Dad has 50+ years of what he calls "solid Catholic teaching," and Mom sadly lands on the side of whoever has the strongest arguments. My brother wants so badly to be more like Dad, that he often shuts off his own brain and jumps on whatever Dad says. Though, to his credit, he honestly likes Matthew, and sticks up for us. Which brings me to the last (and certainly not least!) "category." :-P Love Life This is going to be brief, since I can't entirely talk about this without sounding completely nuts (if you haven't determined that already). But, I love him. I'm in love with him. And he's... well... yeah. Let's just say that I am completely taken aback by him. He knows me often better than I know myself, and understands me to my core. A little unnerving, yes. Scary even. But Matthew is the most beautiful thing to have happened to my life. Its now been about a year since we first started talking. Things are amazing and beautiful and profound and moving all at once. I am the luckiest woman alive. Thank you, Lord. Needless to say, I am not the same as I was upon graduation. But despite the difficult issues with my family and my lack of job, I have more joy than I ever have had in my life! God is truly amazing. :-) I'll update about choir and CCD soon. I don't think I can type anymore right now!

Can you tell I've been doing more reading lately? Heh. In his book Converting the Baptized, Fr. William O'Malley writes about how all too often, Catholics are baptized without having been 'converted.' He says that we/they are too often victims of unmotivated lethargy; we/they are spiritual couch-potatoes who have supposedly given our/their hearts to Christ, but who fail to manifest the joy that is supposed to bring. Some interesting moments: "In the deghettoized, pluralistic society to which we are missioned, one's act of faith in Christ and his Church must be freely and autonomously chosen, or else it cannot survive the assault of so many other powerful and contrary points of view. One cannont survive a dorm debate at NYU or Berkley with nothing more than an uncritically memorized and accepted catechism of answers. If born-again Christians have a better chance in that hostile arena, it is not their memorized chapters-and-verses, but the manifest joy and enthusiasm of their lives and their love for Jesus - which we quite obviously have not managed to inject into the hearts of our own young" (10). "If I had childern, I would very much want them to remain Catholics, but if they chose otherwise, I think I'd be willing to settle for their being saints [holy ones]. I think I'd even rather have good human beings than grudging Catholics. And the choice, after all, however self-impoverishing, would be theirs and not mine" (8). Hmmmm.... "It is more important to know God than to know about God. Surely the Cure of Ars and Joan of Arc are evidence enough of that. And yet we tell youngsters all about God for twelve years and rarely show ways the youngsters can meet this elusive and, to them, mostly academic 'Subject.' Then we assume, since the 'Subject' has been explained so often, that the young understand It, accept It, and will remember It. Such enviable naivete flies directly in the face of every teacher's experience. Moreover, what adult can still rattle off the seven gifts of the Holy Ghost, or the cardinal sins, or any other catechism answers after the first two or three? Nor did memorizing the catechism daunt Adolf Hitler or James Joyce or Fidel Castro. What kept us in the Church was not catechism answers; it was felt faith and hope and love - and need. The answer is not in mere knowledge; the answer is in understanding... let us engage our children in retreats and methods of prayer geared to their receptivities. It is not primarily club members we are training - or even theologians; it is saints. Our primary goal is not mere cognition but the transformation of what being human can mean, the opening of horizons, in a word: conversion" (11,13). "Futhermore, let us be clear that faith is neither a commitment made after every doubt has been laid to rest nor a commitment without the slightest shred of evidence. Faith is both calculated and a risk. Even physics - the 'hardest' of sciences - guarantees only a high degree of probability: trustworthy but not unimprovable. Faith is not certain knowledge; it is a well-researched bet. And anyone who makes a bet without some doubt is either brainless or owns the casino" (15). This book is way cool... more updates to come, I'm sure.

Since I've quit my job at Nordstrom, I've been searching for other jobs that will be able to give me a steady paycheck for doing something that I don't hate. About a week ago, I came across a job opening for "Assistant Preschool Principal" for Chesterbrook Academy (a specialized private school) in Kingstowne. Cool, I thought. Sounds perfect: I'd be working in Education again, but not responsible for daily lesson plans. I would have an administrative side of the job, most likely 9-5, and something I could leave at work at the end of the day. No grading papers or planning more lessons at home in the evenings. And I'd still get to work with kids! So, I applied for the job. Sent in my (fabulous) cover letter, and my updated resume. Waited. A few days later, I recieved an email from the Executive Director for Chesterbrook, with an offer for an interview. WOOHOO! Today was the interview. The good news is, they liked me. They liked me so much, in fact, that I got another interview with the Principal at the Kingstowne school. The bad news? Let's go over the duties involved with this job. As the Assistant Principal, I would be responsible for everything. Yes, everything. As in, if the toilets go on the fritz and the plumber doesn't arrive in time, I'm the one to stand there in my suit and heels with a plunger. Everything, as in: I'd be responsible for maintaining the school's BUDGET. Ha! I'm sorry -- perhaps they should hire an accountant?? I'd be responsible for hiring the teachers (whoa). I'd be responsible for diciplining the already hired teachers, if needed. Yeah. Just a thought, but me, at 23 -- I'm supposed to tell Mrs. Smith, who's been teaching for the past 30 years, how to do her job?? Oh, and let's not forget to mention that I'd be responsible for collecting the payments from the parents (weekly, I might add). I'd also have to dicipline children (which I knew), and make sure the school is properly stocked with supplies, food, etc. Ms.Executive Director said that I'd even have to cook in the kitchen sometimes, if they were down a cook. Was she serious? And wait, here's the best part: the work day isn't 9-5. It's 6:30-6:30. I didn't think I heard correctly at first. But yes. That's right. I'd be working 12 hour work days, 5 days a week. O--K--- so, surely the pay would reflect this, yes? Let's compare. At Nordstrom, my "annual" pay (on average, since it was commission) was ~$27,000. What does Chesterbrook pay its Assistant Principals who do everything??? $28,000. I tried not to laugh/cry. They have to be joking if they think I'm going to work 12 hour work days, doing all kinds of difficult tasks, and only get paid $28,000. So....... thanks, but no thanks. Back to job hunting. :-(

All right. It feels like I haven't updated in a million years! In college, I was updating nearly everyday. I had stuff to post about -- but perhaps more importantly -- TIME to post it in. Not that I don't have stuff to post about now. In fact, I have more than enough to write about. Perhaps even more than in college. The problem is time. Well, shall I say, lack thereof. So here it is. The update. My "breakup" with Matt has been excruciatingly difficult. Emotions come like waves. At some points in the day, I'll hurt, but feel like we're doing the right thing. At other points in the day, the hurt is smaller, and I feel like he and I will be great friends. Other times I feel like my world has ended. Often I feel like an infant who was warmly wrapped in fleecy blankets but then stripped naked to be left screaming and shivering out in the cold; like a part of my heart was just run over by a semi. I don't understand the ocilation of emotion, really. Perhaps its a good sign. A sign that I will someday be able to move on. Someday. Just... maybe not for a while. The problem is, most of the time, I don't want to move on. I mentally know that this decision is best for both he and I. But my heart is still at war with my brain. I crave balance; I want peace. I just don't know how to arrive at it. Anyhow. In other news, my job stinks. Royally. For about a billion reasons. The best way to describe my source of discouragement is "incompatibility" -- essentially, my life and my job are in constant discord. In the summer, it was a fine job. I didn't have any friends, I didn't have any choirs, I wasn't teaching CCD. I didn't have anything to do, other than work. So sure, I could work any and all hours. But now... well, I have a life. And I'm not willing to trade it in or compromise it for a stinky job that I have moral issues with. Yes, moral! I don't like that my entire job is to convince rich ladies that they need more stuff (that they don't really need). I don't like that no matter how much I sell, its never good enough. I'm always supposed to sell more. Even if I have a fabulously good day for sales, I'm supposed to one-up-it the next day. No enjoying your accomplishment. No satisfaction with your good works. In fact, "good works" don't exist in that environment. Heck, its whatever you can use/say/do to make the sale. To make more sales. And then make more more sales. More More More sales. More^infinate sales. (James, did ya like my math reference?!) Heh. UGH. I'm supposed to make people excited about merchandise that I don't find exciting. I'm supposed to make people want STUFF. Nevermind if their buying a $2000 coat will strain their marriage. At least I sold the coat! Nevermind if they're on the fence and don't really want the suit; I'll make 'em lust for it. Its really quite repulsive. And the funny thing is, I still love fashion. I do! But not like this. I love fashion for its art. I love fashion for its attention to detail and fine craftsmanship. Yes, I bought a $200 pair of Elie Tahari pants (but for $78... breathe, people) because they're exquisitely made. Its a hobby for me. My wardrobe is a collection. But its all an art. Not a business. Woe is me for failing to realize the true meaning of "retail." I'm disgusted. On top of that, I'm hitting some nasty red tape. My manager has been giving me Sundays off since I told her that I can't work Sundays due to church and church-related activities (i.e. teaching CCD). For a while everything has been fine. She even told me I should fill out a "Religious Accomidation" form in HR so that in the off chance that she was moved and I had a new manager, my "Sundays off" would be protected. I thanked her immensely for the tip -- I had no idea such a form existed. So I filled it out. And to be extra sure HR wouldn't touch me with a 10-foot-pole, I threw some "religious rhetoric" at them and said that the reason for my accomidation was because as a Catholic Christian, I "observe Holy the Sabbath day." Yeah, I actually said that. Well fast forward to two days after I turned in this form. My manager, Stacey, had a "talk" with me. Apparently, Chris, the head HR lady, called her and was skeptical of my reasoning. "She doesn't need all of Sunday, right?" She said to Stacey. "I mean, church isn't all day. She can work on Sunday nights. She doesn't need the whole day off." Wow. So I explained to Stacey that I teach Sunday School at 4-5:15, and that I can't come in, because I wouldn't get to Nordstrom until 6, and that's when the store closes on Sundays. She looked pained. "Well," she said to me, "I mean, if we ever needed you in the future to come in on Sunday, you know, you might need to do that." Ummmmm.... hello??? I repeated to her my circumstances, and she just said, "well, I know. We haven't needed you on Sundays yet, but I'm just saying just in case, ya know? I mean... this is your job. You have to know where your priorities are." Yeah, lady. I know my priorities. I'm just sorry they don't involve my crappy job. So now I'm in a predicament.... more on that later, as I'm OFF TO WORK...... UGHHHH!!

I thought, "could I give up Catholicism?" Well... I tried to, to an extent. I stepped out of my box and tried something new. And much to my "horror," I saw God in a Baptist church, too. So, I thought, "maybe I can do this..." And for a while, that bothered me. So I started to pray, Lord in Heaven, let me be your instrument. Do with me what you will. I will go where you tell me to go. And then... I waited, listening. My faith grew deeper with Matt's faith, and the more I dug into it, the more meaning my life took on. My life has literally been transformed, though I can't even begin to comment on all of that now (perhaps in a later entry). But then a funny thing happened. I was sitting at Mass a few weeks ago, and it just hit me like a ton of bricks: This Is Right. I Am Catholic. A large part of me wanted to celebrate -- I know what I need to do now, regarding my faith! And then a large part of me felt crushed... I knew what the consequences of this would be. But I didn't say anything about this realization. I figured I'd try to ignore it. Why not enjoy the here and now? Why end something that was truly beautiful? Well, my realization got louder. And Louder. AND LOUDER. Until I was crying nearly every evening -- and even then, I was still trying to ignore the fact that I am Catholic. Why, God?? Why do you do this to me?? So it built up until this weekend, when even Matt noticed something was wrong with me. And then we talked. And this is what we know: He and I believe that within a marriage, both spouses need to be committed to the same church. Baptist? Sure. Catholic? Sure. But its one or the other, not both. So. Since Matt is going to be a Baptist Pastor, I would be the one to have to change if things were to progress. Thus my spiritual warfare: could I abandon Catholocism? I can't. And so that is why he and I can no longer be in a relationship. What would be the point? It would be like "playing house" -- pretending reality was something other than what it is. If long-term is not a possibility, then we run the risk of seriously damaging each other emotionally if we continue in a lie. There is a sense of peace admist all of this too, though. As odd as that is. Despite my tears, there is a sense of relief... of knowing that both he and I are following what God wants for us. And there is joy in that. I am in pain over this, but all I can do is trust in God even when I don't fully understand the "why." The Lord says, "My thoughts are not like your thoughts. Your ways are not like my ways. Just as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways and my thoughts higher than your thoughts." Isaiah 55:8-9 "Come, let's go back to the Lord. He has hurt us, but he will heal us. He has wounded us, but he will bandage our wounds... He will come to us like rain, like the spring rain that waters the ground." Hosea 6:1-3 "My friends, do not be surprised at the terrible trouble which now comes to test you. Do not think that something strange is happening to you. But be happy that you are sharing in Christ's sufferings so that you will be happy and full of joy when Christ comes again in glory." 1 Peter 4:12-13

Yes, I really do. I never imagined how much I would gain from teaching a class of fifth graders about Jesus. I can only pray that they've learned as much from me already as I have from them. Some examples: Two weeks ago, I was giving a lesson on Confirmation and how the Holy Spirit works within us. I explained to the children that the Holy Spirit is the part of our Triune God that wants us to witness our faith. So we brainstormed on the board ways to witness our faith: Profess it. Defend it. Show it. Love it. Know it. Share it. And then Ryan raised his hand and said, "we have to trust our faith too. We have to trust we're in the right religion." I nearly keeeled over. Yes, Ryan! Miss Trayer needs to trust her faith more. The week before that, we learned about the saints. And the last question on their homework assignmet was "How can I, a fifth grade student living in Northern Virginia, be more like this saint?" (they all had to choose one and tell me about him/her). Again Ryan blew me away. He answered, "If I receive a calling, I will follow it. And I will continuously strive to pray." That CHILD!! He's amazing. He just... gets it. Keep in mind here, too, that the rest of the class wrote things like, "I will be nice to people," or "I will give away some of my toys." Fifth grade, people... and Ryan tells me he's going to follow Jesus. Yes, a 10-year-old has managed to completely humble me. But of course this entry wouldn't be complete unless I shared with you all some of the lighter moments, too: In response to the question, "Tell me a little about your saint," one of my two Emilys wrote, "... and then he became an abbot (i.e. miracle worker)." Heehe. I corrected this, of course. So for those of us who don't know (because I didn't have the proper definition before this, either), an abbot is the head monk over a group of 12 (I think!) or more monks. Cool. In response to the "How can I be more like this saint" question, the same Emily wrote, "Well I can't become a hermit monk yet, but I will help people." I love it! In response to that same question, Mary Elizabeth wrote, "I can be a student of my CCD teacher, and a leadership of myself, and I have a convent in my heart (with nuns and guardian angels in my heart?)." I didn't really know what to do with that one. Haahaha... I suppose having a convent in your heart is better than "lusting in your heart" -- so Matt suggested that I save Mary Elizabeth's paper and mail it to her in 10 years. :-P So that's it! I love my class. Every single last one of those kids. I'm going to miss them next year!!

Its talking about our Lord!! The Monteverdi Choir is by far my favorite for rich, authentic, historically accurate (though sometimes with a twist) performances.
